description: Interview with Walter Ram, Jr., Vice-President for Food Safety of Giumarra Companies. He talks about regulations and practices; inspecting food; his desire for sustainable practices and credible food research; the "selling of fear"; and etc. For an interview with Walter Ram, Sr. see: acf2018028_03032

description: Interview with Terry Shannon, Sr., a customhouse broker for the fresh produce industry. The interview took place at Shannon Brokerage on Nelson Avenue in Nogales, Arizona, about 300 feet from the U.S.-Mexico border.

description: Interview with Guy King, retired inspector for Arizona Department of Agriculture. He discusses numerous topics, including his role at Arizona Department of Agriculture; starting out as an inspector; the process of inspection; changes in transportation and facilities; food safety; Mexican produce; work challenges; the USDA grading system; and what makes a good inspector.

description: Interview with Jerry Wagner, retired Director of Sales at Farmer's Best. He discusses numerous topics, including his background in the produce industry; working at Farmer's Best; cucumber-planting in Sinaloa; expanding commodity lines; working with family and learning the trade; cooperation and networking; the social community of Nogales' produce workers; the rise of McAllen and the continued presence of Nogales; the challenges of weather; Canadian vs American consumption of fresh produce; food safety and the stigma of Mexican produce; public interest in food and food trends; and changes in the industry.

description: Interview with Jaime Chamberlain, president of J-C Distributing and former president of the Fresh Produce Association of the Americas. He speaks about a number of topics, including: produce firm and grower relationships; his family's relationships in the trade; "respecting the farm"; the allure of the lifestyle; changes in the industry, specifically the rise of professionalization; the role of politics in the industry; quality versus variety--e.g., tomatoes; growing interest in where food comes from; media stigma, contamination fears, and public anxiety about food; the rise of local produce; and "living through our food."

description: Interview with Axel Holm, a local historian and son of Walter Holm, a major figure in the early years of the Nogales fresh produce industry. Among other topics, Mr. Holm speaks about his family's history; Roy and Titcomb, and the first produce crossings; the start of the railroad; William Raymond "Rame" Morley; Edward R. Harriman and the start of produce trains to Nogales; the development of agriculture in Northwestern Mexico; traveling to Mexico in 1955; agriculture in Sinaloa; European families in the produce industry; mining, the Mexican revolution and the Battle of Nogales; his disinterest in the seasonal industry; the introduction of refrigerated tractor-trailers; the formation of distributors' associations; repacking versus distribution; and etc.
